content:
I have the following tactic state:

p: Prop
h1: ¬¬p → p
h2: ¬¬(p ∨ ¬p)
⊢ p ∨ ¬p

Is it possible to somehow "plug in" h2 to h1 to obtain the goal? Intuitively it seems to me like the answer should be yes, but I'm not sure and none of the tactics I've tried have helped. I'm very much a Lean noob so please forgive me if the answer is blindingly obvious :)
No, it is not possible. In this proof state h1, h2 and the goal are statements about the same specific proposition p.
You cannot just replace p by p ∨ ¬p in h1, because h1 is about p specifically and not about all propositions.
(In fact, it's not possible to deduce this goal from the hypotheses without axioms.)
That makes sense, thanks—my mistake was thinking that because p was an arbitrary Prop I could treat h1 like a statement about all Props as opposed to a statement specifically about p.
Owen Cain has marked this topic as resolved.
